title: The Two Sisters' Unfaithfulness
shortSummary: Ezekiel 23 uses the allegory of two sisters, Aholah and Aholibah, representing Samaria and Jerusalem, to illustrate Israel and Judah's spiritual adultery through idolatry and alliances with foreign nations. The chapter vividly portrays God's judgment on their unfaithfulness and serves as a solemn warning against forsaking Him for worldly powers.
timeline: c. 593 BC - During the Babylonian exile, Ezekiel prophesies against Israel and Judah

keyCharacters.name: Aholah
keyCharacters.description: Symbolizes Samaria, the capital of the northern kingdom of Israel, depicted as the elder sister who committed spiritual adultery through alliances with Assyria.

keyCharacters.name: Aholibah
keyCharacters.description: Represents Jerusalem, the capital of Judah, depicted as the younger sister who was even more corrupt, engaging in idolatry and alliances with Assyria and Babylon.

keyCharacters.name: Assyrians
keyCharacters.description: Foreign rulers and military powers with whom Aholah and Aholibah formed unfaithful alliances, symbolizing idolatry and political unfaithfulness.

keyCharacters.name: Babylonians
keyCharacters.description: Another foreign power representing the later oppressors of Judah, whose seductive allure led Aholibah into further spiritual adultery and eventual judgment.

definitions.definition: A biblical metaphor for spiritual unfaithfulness and idolatry, likening Israel and Judah’s covenant unfaithfulness to prostitution.
An ancient pagan ritual involving child sacrifice to idols, condemned in the Bible as abominable and a sign of deep apostasy.
In prophetic literature, a symbol of shame, exposure, and judgment resulting from sin and unfaithfulness.
A metaphor for experiencing God's judgment or wrath, often representing suffering or punishment due to sin.

outline.heading: Introduction and Allegory of the Two Sisters
outline.description: God introduces the prophetic allegory of two sisters, Aholah and Aholibah, representing Samaria and Jerusalem, who committed spiritual adultery from their youth.

outline.heading: Aholah’s Unfaithfulness and Judgment
outline.description: Aholah (Samaria) is depicted as unfaithful through alliances with Assyria, leading to her capture, loss of children, and death as divine judgment.

outline.heading: Aholibah’s Greater Corruption
outline.description: Aholibah (Jerusalem) is described as more corrupt than her sister, engaging in idolatry and alliances with Assyria and Babylon, recalling her youthful sins in Egypt.

outline.heading: God’s Judgment Pronounced on Aholibah
outline.description: God declares He will bring her lovers—foreign nations—against her in judgment, resulting in violent punishment and the end of her spiritual adultery.

outline.heading: The Abominations and Final Judgment
outline.description: The chapter concludes with a call to judgment against both sisters for their idolatry, child sacrifice, and profaning God’s sanctuary, culminating in their destruction to serve as a warning.

application: Recognize the seriousness of spiritual unfaithfulness and idolatry, avoiding anything that competes with wholehearted devotion to God.
Understand that God’s judgment is certain for persistent sin, urging believers to repent and remain faithful to His covenant.
Avoid forming alliances or dependencies on worldly powers that lead away from trusting God’s provision and protection.
Remember that God’s discipline aims to restore His people and teach future generations to walk in holiness.

keyVerses.text: And the names of them were Aholah the elder, and Aholibah her sister: and they were mine, and they bare sons and daughters. Thus were their names; Samaria is Aholah, and Jerusalem Aholibah.
keyVerses.significance: This verse identifies the allegory, clarifying that the two sisters represent the northern and southern kingdoms, setting the foundation for the entire chapter.

keyVerses.text: That they have committed adultery, and blood is in their hands, and with their idols have they committed adultery, and have also caused their sons, whom they bare unto me, to pass for them through the fire, to devour them.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the grievous sins of idolatry and child sacrifice, emphasizing the depth of Israel and Judah’s rebellion against God.

keyVerses.text: And they shall recompense your lewdness upon you, and ye shall bear the sins of your idols: and ye shall know that I am the Lord GOD.
keyVerses.significance: This closing verse underscores the certainty of divine judgment and the ultimate purpose of God’s discipline—to reveal His sovereignty and holiness.
